sen.j: 給田（きゅうでん）・給畠（きゅうはく）・給田畠（きゅうでんぱく）は、日本の中世において、荘園領主や国衙が、荘官、地頭、年貢運輸者・手工業者などに対して給与した田地または田畠地をいう。
sen.e: Kyuden, Kyuhaku, Kyudenpaku were rice paddies and fields that were paid to shokan (an officer governing shoen (manor)), jito(estate steward), nengu (land tax) couriers and handicraftsmen by shoen holders and the Kokuga (provincial government offices) during the middle ages (Japan).

Kyuden, Kyuhaku and Kyudenpaku were rice paddies and fields that were paid to shokan (an officer governing shoen manor), jito (estate steward), nengu (land tax) couriers and handicraftsmen by shoen holders and the Kokuga (provincial government offices) during the middle ages in Japan.

Kyuden, Kyuhaku and Kyudenpaku were rice paddies and fields that were granted to shokan (an officer governing shoen manor), jito (estate steward), nengu (land tax) couriers and handicraftsmen by shoen holders and the Kokuga (provincial government offices) during the middle ages in Japan.

sen.j: 近世においては、庄屋などの地方三役へ給与された田地を給田と呼んだ。
sen.e: In the modern age, rice fields paid to the three top officers in the village such as the shoya (village headman) were called Kyuden.
In the modern age, rice fields paid to the three top officers in the village such as the shoya (village headman) were called Kyuden.
In the modern age, rice fields granted to the three top officers in the village such as the shoya (village headman) were called Kyuden.

sen.j: 給田（給田畠）は、平安時代末期から鎌倉時代初期までに成立した。
sen.e: Kyuden (Kyudenpaku) were established from the end of the Heian period to the beginning of the Kamakura period.
Kyuden (Kyudenpaku) were established from the end of the Heian period to the beginning of the Kamakura period.
Kyuden (Kyudenpaku) were established from the end of the Heian period to the beginning of the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 当時はちょうど荘園公領制の発展過程の時期にあたり、荘園・国衙領（公領）の運営体制が確立しようとしていた。
sen.e: This was the time when the Shoen koryo (public lands) system was developed and the management system for shoen, kokugaryo(koryo) was being established.
This was the time when the Shoen koryo (public lands) system was developed and the management system for shoen, kokugaryo (koryo) was being established.
This was the time when the Shoen koryo (public lands) system was developed and the management system for shoen, kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office) was being established.

sen.j: 荘園・公領の運営には、運営実務に当たる荘官や、京都の荘園領主（本所）へ年貢などを運送する梶取などの運輸者、本所へ貢納する手工芸品を作る各種職人などの存在が不可欠であり、これら荘官・職人の職務の代償として与えられたのが給田である。
sen.e: The management of shoen and koryo required the existence of shokan, who did the daily management, couriers such as Kajitori who transported the nengu to the shoen landholder (Honsho) in Kyoto and various handicraftsmen who made handicrafts to be given to the Honsho and the payment for the services of shokan and handiscraftsmen were Kyuden.

The management of shoen and koryo required the existence of shokan, who did the daily management, couriers such as Kajitori who transported the nengu to the shoen landholder (Honsho) in Kyoto and various craftsmen who made handicrafts to be given to the Honsho and payment for the services of shokan and craftsmen were Kyuden.

The management of shoen and koryo required the existence of shokan, who did the daily management, couriers such as Kajitori who transported the nengu to the shoen landholder (Honjo) in Kyoto and various craftsmen who made handicrafts to be given to the Honjo and payment for the services of shokan and craftsmen were Kyuden.

sen.j: 平安時代後期（11世紀 - 12世紀）から、郡司・郷司・在庁官人の中に、荒地などを開発して国衙から一定の収取が認められた開発領主へ成長する者が多く現れた。
sen.e: From the late Heian period (eleventh to twelfth century), Gunji (district magistrates), Goji and local kannin (officers) developed abandoned fields and became development landholders who were recognized as having a certain income by the Kokuga.

From the late Heian period (eleventh to twelfth century), Gunji (district magistrates), Goji and local kannin (officers) developed abandoned fields and became development landholders who were recognized as having a certain income by the Kokuga.

From the late Heian period (eleventh to twelfth century), Gunji (district magistrates), Goji (local government official) and local kannin (officers) developed abandoned fields and became development landholders who were recognized as having a certain income by the Kokuga.

sen.j: しかし、開発領主らの持つ収取権（開発所領）は不安定なものであり、常に国衙から剥奪される危険を伴っていた。
sen.e: However the income rights of the development landholders (kaihatsu shoryo) was unstable and was always under the danger of being taken away by the Kokuga.
However the income rights of the development landholders (kaihatsu shoryo) were unstable and always in danger of being taken away by the Kokuga.
However the income rights of the development landholders (kaihatsu shoryo) were unstable and always in danger of being taken away by the Kokuga.

sen.j: そこで、開発領主らは開発所領を有力寺社や有力貴族へ寄進し、田地は荘園となった。
sen.e: Therefore the development landholders donated their kaihatsu shoryo to prominent temples or aristocrats and the rice fields became part of a shoen.
Therefore the development landholders donated their kaihatsu shoryo to prominent temples or aristocrats and the rice fields became part of a shoen.
Therefore the development landholders donated their kaihatsu shoryo to prominent temples, shrines or aristocrats and the rice fields became part of a shoen.

sen.j: 寄進に際して、開発領主は新領主から荘官に任じられるとともに、給田を与えられた。
sen.e: Upon donation, the development landholders were appointed as shokan by the new landholder and were given kyuden.
Upon donation, the development landholders were appointed as shokan by the new landholder and were given kyuden.
Upon donation, the development landholders were appointed as shokan by the new landholder and were given kyuden.

sen.j: このとき、開発領主は国衙から認められた開発所領を失ったが、それと同等か、より多くの田地を給田として与えられることが一般的であった。
sen.e: The development landholder loses the kaihatsu shoryo recognized by the kokuga, but it was conventional that they were given equivalent or more rice fields as Kyuden.
The development landholder loses the kaihatsu shoryo recognized by the kokuga, but it was conventional that they were given equivalent or more rice fields as Kyuden.
The development landholder lost the kaihatsu shoryo recognized by the kokuga, but it was conventional that they were given equivalent or more rice fields as Kyuden.

sen.j: また、開発領主の直営地である佃・堀ノ内・門田なども給田として認められた。
sen.e: Land that was directly under the development landholders control such as Tsukuda, Horinouchi and Monden were recognized as Kyuden.
Land that was directly under the development landholder's control, such as Tsukuda, Horinouchi and Monden, was recognized as Kyuden.
In addition, land that was directly under the development landholder's control, such as Tsukuda, Horinouchi and Monden, was also recognized as Kyuden.

sen.j: 荘官は荘園領主へ年貢・公事を貢納する義務を負っていたが、給田については年貢・公事がすべて免除され、免除分が給田権利者の収入となった。
sen.e: The shokan was responsible for collecting the nengu and kuji (public duties) to the shoen landholder, but the kyuden were exempt from all nengu and kuji (public duties), and the exempt portion was the income of the kyuden right holder.

The shokan was responsible for collecting the nengu and kuji (public duties) for the shoen landholder, but the kyuden were exempt from all nengu and kuji, and the exempt portion was the income of the kyuden right holder.

The shokan was responsible for collecting the nengu and kuji (public duties) for the shoen landholder, but the kyuden were exempt from all nengu and kuji, and the exempt portion was the income of the kyuden right holder.

sen.j: この点が、公事のみが免除される免田（めんでん）、臨時雑役が免除される給名（きゅうみょう）との大きな違いであり、免田・給名と区別するために本給田（ほんきゅうでん）と呼ばれることもあった。
sen.e: This was the most different aspect compared to Menden, which were exempt from only kuji (public duties) and Kyumyo exempt from temporary zoyaku and was called Honkyuden to distinguish it from Menden and Kyumyo

This was the most different aspect compared to Menden, which were exempt from only kuji (public duties), and Kyumyo exempt from temporary zoyaku, and was called Honkyuden to distinguish it from Menden and Kyumyo.

This was the most different aspect compared to Menden, which were exempt from only kuji, and Kyumyo exempt from temporary zoyaku, and was also called Honkyuden to distinguish it from Menden and Kyumyo.

sen.j: 職人給田の多くは国衙の近隣に設定された。
sen.e: Many Shokunin Kyuden were placed close to the Kokuga.
Many Shokunin Kyuden were placed close to the Kokuga.
Many Shokunin Kyuden were placed close to the Kokuga.

sen.j: 元々、国衙機構には多種多様な手工業者が所属し、国衙運営に必要な物資を生産していた。
sen.e: Originally,many handicraftsmen were affiliated with the Kokuga organization and produced the supplies required for Kokuga management.
Originally,many handicraftsmen were affiliated with the Kokuga organization and produced the supplies required for Kokuga management.
Originally,many handicraftsmen were affiliated with the Kokuga organization and produced the supplies required for Kokuga management.

sen.j: その報酬は国衙から給与されていたが、平安後期以降、律令制に基づく国衙機構が大きく変質し再編成が行なわれると、手工業者への報酬に代えて給田が設定されていった。
sen.e: The payment was paid by the Kokuga, but in the late Heian period, the Kokuga organization based on the Ritsuryo system was dramatically reorganized and Kyuden were given to handicraftsmen as payment instead.

The payment was paid by the Kokuga, but in the late Heian period, the Kokuga organization based on the Ritsuryo system was dramatically reorganized and Kyuden were given to handicraftsmen as payment instead.

The payment was paid by the Kokuga, but in the late Heian period, the Kokuga organization based on the Ritsuryo system was dramatically reorganized and Kyuden were given to handicraftsmen as payment instead.

sen.j: 荘園においても、荘園領主らは必要物資を得るために荘園内に手工業者・職人を確保し、職能に応じて彼らへ給田を与えていった。
sen.e: As for Shoen, shoen landholders kept handicraftsmen within their shoen to obtain necessary supplies and gave Kyuden according to their ability.
As for Shoen, shoen landholders kept handicraftsmen within their shoen to obtain necessary supplies and gave Kyuden according to their ability.
As for Shoen, shoen landholders kept handicraftsmen within their shoen to obtain necessary supplies and gave Kyuden according to their ability.

sen.j: 13世紀前半の承久の乱以降、新補地頭に対して荘園公領11町当たり1町の給田を与える新補率法が成立すると、実際には1町にとどまらず2町・3町の給田を設定する例が多く見られ、新補地頭による荘園公領侵出を強く後押しした。
sen.e: After the Jyokyu Disturbance in the early thirteenth century, the Shinpo rippo (the regulation regarding new Jito appointments) was established to give 1-cho of kyuden per 11-cho of shoen koryo to newly appointed jito, but in actuality, there were many cases were two or even three-cho of kyuden were given, strongly pushing the invasion of newly appointed jito into shoen koryo.

After the Jyokyu Disturbance in the early thirteenth century, the Shinpo rippo (the regulation regarding new Jito appointments) was established to give 1 cho of kyuden per 11 cho of shoen koryo to newly appointed jito, but in actuality, there were many cases were two or even three cho of kyuden were given, strongly pushing the invasion of newly appointed jito into shoen koryo.

After the Jyokyu War in the early thirteenth century, the Shinpo rippo (the regulation regarding new Jito appointments) was established to give 1 cho of kyuden per 11 cho of shoen koryo to newly appointed jito, but in actuality, there were many cases where two or even three cho of kyuden were given, strongly pushing the invasion of newly appointed jito into shoen koryo.

sen.j: 給田の経営は、はじめ自らの下人・所従らを駆使して行なわれていたが、時代が下るにつれ、荘園内の名主・百姓らへ請作に出して行なわれていったと考えられている。
sen.e: The management of shoen was first done by using their own servants and followers, but as the ages went on, ukesaku (leasing out) to the nanushi (village headman) and farmers within the shoen was done.
The management of shoen was first done using their own servants and followers, but as the ages went on, leasing out to the village headman and farmers within the shoen became the practice.
The management of shoen was first done using their own servants and followers, but as the ages went on, leasing out to the village headman and farmers within the shoen became the practice.

sen.j: 中世の給田は、荘官等へ給与する荘官給田、年貢輸送者や手工業者へ給与する職人給田に大きく分けられる。
sen.e: Kyuden in the middle ages were largely classified into Shokan kyuden given to shokan, shokunin kyuden given to nengu couriers and handicraftsmen.
Kyuden in the middle ages were largely classified into Shokan kyuden given to shokan, and shokunin kyuden given to nengu couriers and handicraftsmen.
Kyuden in the middle ages were largely classified into Shokan kyuden given to shokan, and shokunin kyuden given to nengu couriers and handicraftsmen.

sen.j: 荘官給田には、預所給、地頭給、公文給、下司給、田所給、惣追捕使給、刀禰給、番頭給、定使給、案主給、名主給、職事給、散仕給、図師給、公人給などがあった。
sen.e: Shokan kyuden were classified into Azukaridokoro (a deputy of "Shoen" manor lord)kyu, Jitokyu, kumon (a local shoen official)kyu, Geshi (A local keeper)ikyu, Tadokorokyu, Sotsuibushi (government post in charge of police and military roles)kyu, Tonekyu, Bantokyu, Jotsukai (a lower-ranked officer who governs Shoen manor)kyu, Anju (officer who recorded and stored documents at Shoens, authorities) kyu, Nanushi (village headman) kyu,Shikiji(a person with an official rank but has no corresponding position)kyu, Sanshikyu, Zushi (temporary officer who made maps of rice fields)kyu, Kunin(low ranking staff who did odd jobs)kyu, etc.

Shokan kyuden were classified into Azukaridokoro (a deputy of "Shoen" manor lord), Jitokyu, kumon (a local shoen official), Geshi (a local keeper), Tadokorokyu, Sotsuibushi (government post in charge of police and military roles), Tonekyu, Bantokyu, Jotsukai (a lower-ranked officer who governs Shoen manor), Anju (officer who recorded and stored documents at Shoens, authorities), Nanushi (village headman), Shikiji (a person with an official rank but has no corresponding position), Sanshikyu, Zushi (temporary officer who made maps of rice fields), Kunin (low ranking staff who did odd jobs), etc.

Shokan kyuden were classified into Azukaridokoro (a deputy of "Shoen" manor lord) kyu, Jitokyu, Kumon (a local shoen official) kyu, Geshi (a local keeper) kyu, Tadokorokyu, Sotsuibushi (government post in charge of police and military roles) kyu, Tonekyu, Bantokyu, Jotsukai (a lower-ranked officer who governs Shoen manor) kyu, Anju (officer who recorded and stored documents at Shoens, authorities) kyu, Nanushi (village headman) kyu, Shikiji (a person with an official rank but has no corresponding position) kyu, Sanshikyu, Zushi (temporary officer who made maps of rice fields) kyu, Kunin (low ranking staff who did odd jobs) kyu, etc.

sen.j: 職人給田には、梶取給、夫領給、船給、鍛冶給、番匠給、絵所給、檜物給、土器作給、道々工等例給などがあった。
sen.e: Shokunin kyuden included Kajitori(rower)kyu, Furyokyu, Fune(ship)kyu, Kaji(blacksmith)kyu, Bansho(builder)kyu, Edorkoro(art office)kyu, Himono(craft of bending Hinoki bark) kyu, Dokisaku (pottery) kyu, Dodoukutorei (road building) kyu

Shokunin kyuden included Kajitori (rower), Furyokyu, Fune (ship), Kaji (blacksmith), Bansho (builder), Edokoro (art office), Himono (craft of bending Hinoki bark), Dokisaku (pottery) and Dodoukutorei (road building).

Shokunin kyuden included Kajitori (rower) kyu, Furyokyu, Fune (ship) kyu, Kaji (blacksmith) kyu, Bansho (builder) kyu, Edokoro (art office) kyu, Himono (craft of bending Hinoki bark) kyu, Dokisaku (pottery) kyu and Dodoukutorei (road building) kyu.

sen.j: 中世末期まで継続した給田は、形を変えて近世にも引き継がれた。
sen.e: Kyuden continued into the late middle ages and was passed onto the modern ages with some transformation.
Kyuden continued into the late middle ages and were passed on to the modern age with some changes.
Kyuden continued into the late middle ages and were passed on to the modern age with some changes.

sen.j: 近世には主に庄屋をはじめとする村役人に対して給田が設定された。
sen.e: In the modern ages, kyuden were designated mainly for village officials such as Shoya.
In the modern ages, kyuden were designated mainly for village officials such as Shoya.
In the modern ages, kyuden were designated mainly for village officials such as Shoya.

sen.j: 役給田・庄屋給田ともいう。
sen.e: It was called Yakukyuden or Shoyakyuden.
It was called Yakukyuden or Shoyakyuden.
It was also called Yakukyuden or Shoyakyuden.

sen.j: また職人や廻船業者へ与えられた給田もあり、小給などと呼ばれた。
sen.e: There were also Kyuden given to handicraftmen and Kaisengyosha and were called Shokyu.
There were also Kyuden given to handicraftsmen and Kaisengyosha, which were called Shokyu.
There were also Kyuden given to handicraftsmen and Kaisengyosha (shipping agents), which were called Shokyu.

sen.j: 近世の給田は江戸時代を通じて見られた。
sen.e: Kyuden in the modern ages were seen throughout the Edo Period.
Kyuden in the modern ages were seen throughout the Edo Period.
Kyuden in the modern ages were seen throughout the Edo Period.

sen.j: 藩主から庄屋などへ与えられた給田は、年貢が免除されていた。
sen.e: Kyuden given to Shoya from the domain lord were exempt from yearly tax.
Kyuden given to Shoya from the domain lord were exempt from yearly tax.
Kyuden given to Shoya from the domain lord were exempt from land tax.

sen.j: 藩財政の事情によっては、課税が復活した事例もある。
sen.e: In some cases, exemption from tax was taken away because of the financial situation of the domain.
In some cases, exemption from tax was taken away because of the financial situation of the domain.
In some cases, exemption from tax was taken away because of the financial situation of the domain.

sen.j: 中世・近世の給田に由来する給田地名が、全国各地にある。
sen.e: Kyuden place names derived from kyuden in the middle ages and modern ages are found throughout the nation.
Kyuden place names derived from kyuden in the middle ages and modern ages are found throughout the nation.
Kyuden place names derived from kyuden in the middle ages and modern ages are found throughout the nation.

sen.j: 主なものに、千葉県長生郡長南町給田、東京都世田谷区給田 (世田谷区)、静岡県沼津市下香貫給田などがある。
sen.e: Main examples are Kyuden, Chonan-cho, Chosei-gun, Chiba Prefecture, Kyuden, Sedagaya Ward, Tokyo, Kyuden, Shimokanuki, Numazu City, Shizuoka Prefecture.
Main examples are Kyuden, Chonan-cho, Chosei-gun, Chiba Prefecture, Kyuden, Sedagaya Ward, Tokyo, Kyuden, Shimokanuki, Numazu City, Shizuoka Prefecture.
Main examples are Kyuden, Chonan-cho, Chosei-gun, Chiba Prefecture, Kyuden, Sedagaya Ward, Tokyo, Kyuden, Shimokanuki, Numazu City, Shizuoka Prefecture.

sen.j: その他、久門給（公文給。山口県岩国市玖珂町）、地頭給（岡山県赤磐市、福岡県前原市）、鍛冶給（高知県南国市、福岡県古賀市）、番匠給（山口県防府市、神奈川県横浜市戸塚区）、飛田給（・上ヶ給）（東京都調布市）など、給田に由来する地名が今も各地に残存している。
sen.e: Others: Kumonkyu(Kumonkyu
Others: Kumonkyu (Kumonkyu

Others: Kumonkyu (Kuga-cho, Iwakuni City, Yamaguchi Prefecture), Jitokyu (Akaiwa City, Okayama Prefecture, Maebaru City, Fukuoka Prefecture), Kajikyu (Nankoku City, Kochi Prefecture, Koga City, Fukuoka Prefecture), Banshokyu (Hofu City, Yamaguchi Prefecture, Totsuka Ward, Yokohama City, Kanagawa Prefecture) and Tobitakyu (Kamigakyu, Chofu City, Tokyo) are examples of place names originating from Kyuden that are still in use today throughout the nation.
sen.cmt: 久門給（公文給はローマ字にすると同じになり重複するので一つを削除しました。下の文を統合しました。
